dialog-modal-model-creation.html.source:
{{title}}

You can not directly create a model.

To create a model, you have to create a schema and then a model will be generated based on your schema definition.

dialog-modal-component-info.html.source:
{{title}}

By default all your models inherit from _Component. It adds to your models a set of APIs to:

- manage your components,

- add/remove listeners to components events and

- require components.

You can remove this inheritance for your needs.

export-app-github.html.source:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>

<head>
  <title>{{name}}</title>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <!-- system -->
  <link rel="system" type="application/json" href="{{name}}.json">
</head>

<body>
  <!-- system runtime  -->
  <script log="{{logLevel}}" src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/system-runtime@2.2.0/dist/system-runtime.min.js"></script>
</body>

</html>

export-app.html.source:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>

<head>
    <title>{{name}}</title>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
</head>

<body>
    <!-- System Runtime -->
    <script>
{{library}}
    </script>
    <!-- system -->
    <script>
    runtime.on('ready', function ready() {
        // set the level of log
        this.require('logger').level('{{logLevel}}');
        // install and start the system
        this.install({{system}});
    }, false, true);
    </script>
</body>

</html>

help-behaviors.html.source: A behavior is the action to do when a method or an event is called.

help-components.html.source: Components are the store of your objects.

help-logs.html.source:
You will find here the logs of the running app.

Example of log:

this
.require('logger')
.info('hello world');

help-models.html.source: A model is an UML representation of your classes.

help-schemas.html.source: A schema is the definition of your model. Models are generated based on the schema definition.

help-system.html.source: An application is a system. Once you have created one, your next step is to create a schema.

help-types.html.source: A type is used in your model to define an enumeration or a structure.

source.name: TodoMVC
source.description:
Create a Todo manager.

The purpose of this example is to learn how to code in System Designer.

Taken from TodoMVC, http://todomvc.com.

Based on the work made by TasteJS (under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License).

info.template:
Double-click to edit a todo

Created by System Designer

Part of TodoMVC

footer.template:
{nbItems} {item} left
  • All
  • Active
  • Completed

todoapp.template: todos

toggleall.template:
<input class="toggle-all" type="checkbox">
<label for="toggle-all">Mark all as complete</label>

source.name: example-dvd-collection
source.description:
Create a DVD collection manager

This system shows a list of DVD.

note: if you create a DVD Component when running the application, the list will be automatically updated

source.name: WebComponents
source.description:
Create Web Components

1. The tag <mywidget message="hello world !"/> is added to the body of the page
2. This tag calls the Component MyWidget
3. It generates an input and a span tag that are binded: the value in the span change if you change the input value

note: the purpose of the example is to show how easily you can create Web Component, and we show only one way to do that

source.name: example-node
source.description:
Create a server application

This example shows you how to create a Node.js application in System Designer.

You can the test the application directly in System Designer (* macOS and windows versions only).

note: use 'global.require' instead of 'require' to require a module.

source.name: REST-Server
source.description:
Create a REST server

1. Create a schema, example 'Book', make it inherit from 'SyncComponent', add properties
2. Create 'Book' components
3. Run the application (* System Designer macOS and windows versions only)
4. Now you can send GET/POST/PUT/DELETE/PATCH requests to http://127.0.0.1:8080/rest/Book

note: because the running application and System Designer are synchronized, if you open the 'Components' tab when performing the requests, you will see directly the modification on the panel (i.e. if you delete a component with a DELETE request, it will be removed from System Designer)

source.name: REST-Client
source.description:
Create a REST client

1. Create a schema, example 'Book', make it inherit from 'SyncComponent', add properties
2. Create Book components
3. Run the application
4. Now all modications to Book components, will send POST/DELETE/PATCH requests to the server

note: you use this system with the 'REST server' example:

1. Import 'REST server
2. Create the same schema as in 'REST Client', make it inherit from 'SyncComponent', add properties
3. Export 'REST server' example in node.js format
4. Export 'REST client' example in HTML format 
5. Copy the generated HTML next to your 'REST server' example
6. Run the server
7. Go to http://127.0.0.1:8080/REST-Client.html. All modifications to the synchonized components will be send to the server.

warning: this system uses fetch API, so it does not work on Interner Explorer.

source.name: FilterList
source.description:
Create a list

1. Create a schema, example 'Book', add properties
2. Create 'Book' components
3. Open 'list' component, and set 'model' property to 'Book'
3. Run the application
4. You see the list of your components and you can filter that list

template.source: Filter

source.name: system-channel
source.description:
Send messages threw a channel


You can send messages from one system to another system with channels. To do that:

1. Define an event with parameters in '_Channel' schema and model
2. In '_Channel' 'send' method, define how to send the message to another channel (webRTC, XHR, ...)
3. Define how to get the message and send it to the current system with 'runtime.message' API

Then:

- to send a message: 
this.require('channel').myevent(param1, param2, ...)

- to listen to a message: 
this.require('channel').on('myevent', function myevent(data) {})

source.name: helper-database-events
source.description:
Use System Runtime NoSQL Database events

System Runtime NoSQL Database is an instance of '_Database' class that sends insert, update and remove events for each collection of the database.

You can listen to all these events to perform the action you want.

note: events are send for the collections (i.e. schemas) you have created but also for the private collections of the database.

source.name: extension-template
source.description:
Create an extension

Extension for creating:

* menubar items,
* toolbar items,
* actions when clicking on them and
* show modal dialog.
